Topic.Title: Dividend News

Message.Msg: I would not expect much of a dividend increase during 2013. BAC still needs to save funds to cover mortgages w/ freddie & privates. We will be lucky if they are able to pay $.05-.10c per quarter. I believe they will want to start buying back shares to reduce the number of outstanding shares. Dilution hit BAC hard during the downturn. I would like to see a $3 Billion buyback approved by bank management & fed. The real dividend gains will come in 2014 and 2015. I think BAC could be $35 stock paying $.25 per quarter by June 2015.

Message.Title: BAC moving up!!
Message.Msg: Put aside your feeling for BAC (love/hate), the company just makes money. The mortgage mess will not bankrupt the company and even though they could have put countrywide into bankruptcy, the management has committed to paying in order to make amends for another company's transgression. This decision is not sitting well with shareholders right now but the CEO can sleep better at night and I am okay with that for now. 2013 is the first year in which BAC can start making amends to shareholders and I think it will start with buybacks. I would not expect much of a dividend increase during 2013. BAC still needs to save funds to cover mortgages w/ freddie & privates. We will be lucky if they are able to pay $.05-.10c per quarter. I believe they will want to start buying back shares to reduce the number of outstanding shares. Dilution hit BAC hard during the downturn. I would like to see a $3 Billion buyback approved by bank management & fed. The real dividend gains & buybacks will come in 2014 and 2015. I think BAC could be $35 stock paying $.25 per quarter by June 2015.

Message.Title: Bank of America Freezes Gun Manufacturer's Account, Company Owner Claims! OMG!
Message.Msg: Bank of America Freezes Gun Manufacturer's Account, Company Owner Claims By Gregory Gwyn-Williams, Jr. January 7, 2013 Subscribe to Gregory Gwyn-Williams, Jr.'s posts Bank of America has reportedly frozen the account of gun manufacturer American Spirit Arms, according to its owner, Joe Sirochman. In a Facebook post dated December 29, Sirochman wrote the following: “My name is Joe Sirochman owner of American Spirit Arms...our Web site orders have jumped 500 percent causing our Web site e-commerce processing larger deposits to Bank of America. So they decided to hold the deposits for further review. “After countless hours on the phone with Bank of America, I finally got a manager in the right department that told me the reason that the deposits were on hold for further review -- her exact words were -- ‘We believe you should not be selling guns and parts on the Internet.’”(emphasis added) Sirochman also wrote that he told the bank manager that “they have no right to make up their own new rules and regs” and that “[American Spirit is a] firearms manufacturer with all the proper licensing.” He also noted that he has been doing business with Bank of America for over 10 years, but will now be looking for a new bank. According to Unlawful News, this isn't the first time Bank of America has targeted a customer involved in the firearms industry. McMillan Group International was reportedly told that its business was no longer welcome after the company started manufacturing firearms – even after 12 years of doing business with the bank.

Topic.Title: Anybody else see a near-term technical correction?

Message.Msg: At this point, given the action of the last two sessions, yes. It's been pulled from ~$12.40 two sessions back to where it now sits in PM, at $11.80. That's roughly a 5% correction already. But, BAC is now about half-way back into the gap that opened from ~$11.65 to ~$12.05 on Jan 2. Closing that gap would mean taking the bid back to that ~$11.65 level, with a high probability of overshooting that line should it happen. A 10 day 10min TA chart shows the stoch's now turning up from oversold, a positive, but CS's change means a the bid should continue to be under pressure today. I'm a buyer in BAC, longer term, on anything below the .80 line, but I'm also patient and not in any hurry. There's no need to chase BAC here. Let this period play out and consolidate, and wait on your long sided set-up. And if you're playing the short game going short under $12 is/was optimum...and if you're trading it then shorting in the mid $11.80's, for 10pennies or more (it's a trade after all) has a high success probability to it. Just my 2pennies worth Now let's see what actually happens today. Highlow American Net'Zen

Message.Title: Pennsylvania Democrat fails at 2 suicide attempts on interstate before work
Message.Msg: Pennsylvania Democrat fails at 2 suicide attempts on interstate before work Published January 09, 2013 Associated Press CANONSBURG, Pa. – State police say a Gay Black/Hispanic Union worker/community organizer twice tried to kill himself on Interstate 79 in southwestern Pennsylvania before going to work. The Associated Press is not identifying the 22-year-old Washington, Pa. man because of the nature of the incidents and also because the Obama administration has disclosed to AP that the young man was despondent about not being appointed for a Northern Pa judgeship, but police say he first tried to end his life by jumping out of a moving vehicle that was driving him to work in Canonsburg, about 15 miles south of Pittsburgh. That happened about 7:45 a.m. Tuesday. About a half hour later, police say the man stepped over a guide rail into the path of a tractor-trailer which tried to avoid the man but knocked him out of his shoes. Troopers from the Washington barracks say the man jumped up, grabbed his shoes, slid down a hillside and walked to work. He was since been flown to a Pittsburgh hospital.

Message.Title: THE NEW UNCLE SAM ECONOMY
Message.Msg: With markets paused remained lower on Tuesday with some temporary sanity following the end of the year insanity, we learned that 2013, just like the end of 2012, may be the year of the borrower. Consumer credit rose in November for the fourth straight month, beating expectations. The Federal Reserve said on Tuesday consumer credit increased by $16.05 billion in November after rising by a slightly revised $14.08 billion in October. While some may take this as a positive sign for the economy, we of course know better. If this was driven even remotely by actual short-term consumption demand, it would likely be a good sign, as it would imply consumers have more faith in being able to repay their credit cards. Sadly, of the entire $16 billion jump, only $817 million, or 5%, was based on a jump in revolving credit. The real "growth" came as usual, courtesy of Uncle Sam handouts, solely in the form of auto and student loans, which accounted for a whopping $15.2 billion of the increase in consumer debt, the second largest jump in the year, second only to the $18 billion in January. For all of 2012, a whopping $130 billion of the $137 billion total has been in the form of government handouts. In other words, nearly 1% of 2012 GDP has been funded by Uncle Sam. And yes you can repossess a car if you don’t repay your loan, but it’s pretty difficult to repossesses a degree. CAPITALISM IS DEAD!!!!
